abstract: A dire new forecast for global vehicle sales battered the shares of auto companies on Thursday, particularly General Motors, whose stock plunged more than 31 percent.
snippet: A dire new forecast for global vehicle sales battered the shares of auto companies on Thursday, particularly General Motors, whose stock plunged more than 31 percent.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT  A dire new forecast for global vehicle sales battered the shares of auto companies on Thursday, particularly General Motors, whose stock plunged more than 31 percent and was the hardest hit of the 30 companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

headline.main: U.S. Auto Shares Plunge on a Grim Sales Forecast
headline.print_headline: U.S. Auto Shares Plunge On a Grim Sales Forecast

abstract: Global stocks plummeted Friday after the rout Thursday on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 7.3 percent, or 678 points, closing below the 9,000-mark for the first time since 2003, The New York Times’s David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.
lead_paragraph: Global stocks plummeted Friday after the rout Thursday on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 7.3 percent, or 678 points, closing below the 9,000-mark for the first time since 2003, The New York Times’s David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.

headline.main: Markets in Europe and Asia Plunge

abstract: Quick Bits: Ad sales are slowing, start-ups are stopping and it’s a great time to buy a tech company if you still have money in the bank (and the bank hasn’t failed).
snippet: Quick Bits: Ad sales are slowing, start-ups are stopping and it’s a great time to buy a tech company if you still have money in the bank (and the bank hasn’t failed).
lead_paragraph: Watching the stock market this morning has been like attending a bungee jumpers convention. (“Does his cord look like it’s a little frayed?”) Meanwhile it doesn’t matter whether the Dow is 9,000, 8,000 or 7,000 for tech companies to realize they need to pull away from the cliff as fast as they can. Signs of turmoil abound:

abstract: That is what CNBC says about a week that saw the market drop by some 18 percent. Every day brought yet another triple digit loss, the worst being Thursday’s 679-point drop. And as usual, the credit markets were even worse, if that’s possible. My column on Saturday is a meditation on why human beings — knowing what we know about the bouts of financial insanity that led to previous bubbles — can’t seem to prevent them from happening. It turns out that preventing crashes is something we’re just not able to learn from history.
lead_paragraph: That is what CNBC says about a week that saw the market drop by some 18 percent. Every day brought yet another triple digit loss, the worst being Thursday’s 679-point drop. And as usual, the credit markets were even worse, if that’s possible. My column on Saturday is a meditation on why human beings — knowing what we know about the bouts of financial insanity that led to previous bubbles — can’t seem to prevent them from happening. It turns out that preventing crashes is something we’re just not able to learn from history.

headline.main: The Worst Week Ever for the Dow
